column1:
you may go into the fields
or down the lane, but don't go
into Mr. McGregor's garden:
your Father had an accident
there; he was put in a pie by
Mrs. McGregor.

NOW run along, and don't
get into mischief. I am
going out.

One table-spoonful to be
taken at bed-time.

Cotton-tail! Cotton-tail!
fetch some more camomile!

It spoils people's clothes
to squeeze under a gate; the
proper way to get in, is to
climb down a pear tree.

One, two, three, four, five,
six leetle rabbits!

EH? What's that? What
have they been spoiling
now?

One, two, three, four, five,
six leetle fat rabbits!

Don't you be silly; what
do you mean, you silly old
man?

In the sack! one, two, three,
four, five, six!

Not fit to eat; but the
skins will do fine to line my
old cloak.

Rabbit tobacco! I shall
skin them and cut off their
heads.

He's a bad kitten, Cousin Tabitha; he
made a cat's cradle of my best bonnet last
time I came to tea. Where have you looked
for him?

I'm not afraid of rats; I will help you
to find him; and whip him too! What is
all that soot in the fender?

The chimney wants sweeping--Oh, dear
me, Cousin Ribby--now Moppet and Mittens
are gone!

They have both got out of the cup-
board!
Yes, it is infested with rats,

column18:
I caught seven young
ones out of one hole in the back kitchen,
and we had them for dinner last Saturday.
And once I saw the old father rat--an
enormous old rat, Cousin Ribby. I was
just going to jump upon him, when he
showed his yellow teeth at me and whisked
down the hole.

column1:
The rats get upon my nerves, Cousin
Ribby,

there's been an old woman rat in the
kitchen, and she's stolen some of the
dough!
Which way did she go, Moppet?

Oh! Mother, Mother, there has been an
old man rat in the dairy--a dreadful 'normous
big rat, Mother; and he's stolen a pat
of butter and the rolling-pin.

column27:
We must send for John Joiner at
once, with a saw.

column1:
I cannot go back. If I slipped I might
fall in the fire and singe my beautiful tail
and my little blue jacket.

What do you mean by tumbling into
my bed all covered with smuts?
Please sir, the chimney wants sweeping,

Anna Maria, make me a kitten dumpling
roly-poly pudding for my dinner.

His tail is sticking out! You did not
fetch enough dough, Anna Maria.
I fetched as much as I could carry,

We are discovered and interrupted,
Anna Maria; let us collect our property,--
and other people's,--and depart at once.

I fear that we shall be obliged to leave
this pudding.

But I am persuaded that the knots would
have proved indigestible, whatever you may
urge to the contrary.

Come away at once and help me to tie up
some mutton bones in a counterpane,

column18:
I have got half a smoked
ham hidden in the chimney.

column1:
a glass of my daughter Flopsy's
cowslip wine.

Whatever is the matter, Cousin
Benjamin? Is it a cat? or John
Stoat Ferret?

No, no, no! He's bagged my
family--Tommy Brock--in a sack
--have you seen him?

Tommy Brock? how many,
Cousin Benjamin?

Seven, Cousin Peter, and all of
them twins! Did he come this
way? Please tell me quick!

Yes, yes; not ten minutes since
. . . . he said they were caterpillars;
I did think they were kicking rather
hard, for caterpillars.

Which way? which way has he
gone, Cousin Peter?

but there are two hopeful
circumstances. Your family is alive and
kicking; and Tommy Brock has
had refreshment. He will probably
go to sleep, and keep them
for breakfast.

Cousin Benjamin, compose
yourself. I know very well which way.
Because Mr. Tod was at home in
the stick-house he has gone to
Mr. Tod's other house, at the top
of Bull Banks. I partly know,
because he offered to leave any
message at Sister Cottontail's; he
said he would be passing.

He must be very puffed; we
are close behind him, by the scent.
What a nasty person!

Oh my poor rabbit babies! What
a dreadful place; I shall never see
them again!

It will make a great mess in
my bedroom; but I could never
sleep in that bed again without a
spring cleaning of some sort,

I will wash the tablecloth and
spread it on the grass in the sun to
bleach. And the blanket must be
hung up in the wind; and the bed
must be thoroughly disinfected, and
aired with a warming-pan; and
warmed with a hot-water bottle.

I will get soft soap, and monkey
soap, and all sorts of soap; and
soda and scrubbing brushes; and
persian powder; and carbolic to
remove the smell. I must have a
disinfecting. Perhaps I may have
to burn sulphur.

First I will arrange the hole--
then I will drag out that person in
the blanket . . .

Now for it! Run in, Cousin
Benjamin! Run in and get them
while I watch at the door.
Oh; oh! they are coming back!

What dreadful bad language!
I think they have fallen down the
stone quarry.

Be quick, it's all right. Shut
the oven door, Cousin Benjamin,
so that he won't miss them.

I've got them! Can we get away?
Shall we hide, Cousin Peter?

Sally Henny-penny, has
YOU found three pocket-handkins?

AND what are those long
yellow things with fingers
like gloves?

WHY, there's another
handkersniff--but it
isn't mine; it's red?

Oh no, if you please'm;
that one belongs to old Mrs.
Rabbit; and it DID so smell
of onions! I've had to wash
it separately, I can't get out
the smell.

WHAT are those funny
little white things?

That's a pair of mittens
belonging to Tabby Kitten; I
only have to iron them; she
washes them herself.

AND what are you dipping
into the basin of starch?

They're little dicky shirt-
fronts belonging to Tom Titmouse
--most terrible particular!

Now I've finished my ironing;
I'm going to air some clothes.

WHAT are these dear soft
fluffy things?

Oh those are wooly coats
belonging to the little lambs
at Skelghyl.

It is very unpleasant, I am
afraid of the police,

It is your own fault for being
a terrier; _I_ do not require a licence,
and neither does Kep, the Collie
dog.

It is very uncomfortable, I am
afraid I shall be summoned. I
have tried in vain to get a licence
upon credit at the Post Office;

column18:
The place is full of
policemen. I met one as I was
coming home.

column1:
Let us send in the bill again to
Samuel Whiskers, Ginger, he owes
22/9 for bacon.

I do not believe that he intends
to pay at all,

And I feel sure that Anna
Maria pockets things-- Where
are all the cream crackers?

Samuel Whiskers has run up
a bill as long as his tail; he has
had an ounce and three-quarters of
snuff since October.

What is seven pounds of butter
at 1/3, and a stick of sealing wax
and four matches?

Send in all the bills again to
everybody 'with compts'

Do you think that he has gone
to fetch a real live policeman? I
am afraid it is a summons,

Henny's Opening Sale! Grand
co-operative Jumble! Penny's
penny prices! Come buy, come
try, come buy!

column27:
If I catch more than
five fish, I will invite my
friends Mr. Alderman Ptolemy
Tortoise and Sir Isaac Newton.
The Alderman, however, eats
salad.

column1:
I will eat a butterfly
sandwich, and wait till the
shower is over,
I trust that is not a rat,

A minnow! a minnow! I
have him by the nose!

WHAT a mercy that was
not a pike!

How shall you ever get
them out again? It is like a
money-box!

I shall be much thinner
before spring-time, my love,

Who's bin digging-up MY
nuts? Who's-been-digging-
up MY nuts?

Timmy Tiptoes! Timmy
Tiptoes! Oh, where is Timmy
Tiptoes?

IT is getting perfectly full-
up down-stairs; the
sitting-room is full, and they are
rolling along the passage; and
my husband, Chippy Hackee,
has run away and left me.
What is the explanation of
these showers of nuts?

I am sure I beg your
pardon; I did not not know that
anybody lived here,

You could squeeze in,
through that little
round hole,

column18:
but my
husband, Chippy Hackee,
bites!

Is that you,
Goody Tiptoes? Why, certainly!

column1: I thank you kindly, little dog, I fare as well as you!

I really couldn't, COULDN'T eat
mouse pie. And I shall have to
eat it, because it is a party. And
MY pie was going to be veal and
ham. A pink and white pie-dish!
and so is mine; just like Ribby's
dishes; they were both bought at
Tabitha Twitchit's.

It is all ready to put into the
oven. Such lovely pie-crust; and
I put in a little tin patty-pan to
hold up the crust; and I made a
hole in the middle with a fork to
let out the steam--Oh I do wish I
could eat my own pie, instead of a
pie made of mouse!

A pink and white pie-dish-and
YOU shall eat it all. 'You' means
me--then Ribby is not going to
even taste the pie herself? A pink
and white pie-dish! Ribby is sure
to go out to buy the muffins. . . . .
Oh what a good idea! Why
shouldn't I rush along and put my
pie into Ribby's oven when Ribby
isn't there?
The top oven bakes too quickly,

I trust that is not that Pie: the
spoons are locked up, however,

It is a very odd thing that
Ribby's pie was NOT in the oven
when I put mine in! And I can t
find it anywhere; I have looked all
over the house. I put MY pie into
a nice hot oven at the top. I could
not turn any of the other handles;
I think that they are all shams,

column18:
but I wish I could
have removed the pie made of
mouse! I cannot think what she
has done with it? I heard Ribby
coming and I had to run out by the
back door!

column1:
I did not THINK I left that drawer
pulled out; has somebody been
trying on my mittens?

the top one would certainly
have been very much too hot. I
wonder why that cupboard door
was open? Can there really have
been some one in the house?

I wonder if Ribby has taken
MY pie out of the oven yet?

column27:
and whatever can have
become of the other pie made of
mouse?

column1:
Come in! and how do you do,
my dear Duchess?
I hope I see you well?

Quite well, I thank you, and
how do YOU do, my dear Ribby?

column18:
I've brought you
some flowers; what a delicious
smell of pie!

column1:
Oh, what lovely flowers! Yes,
it is mouse and bacon!

Oh yes, please! my dear
Ribby; and may I have a lump
upon my nose?

How good that pie smells! I
do love veal and ham--I mean to
say mouse and bacon----

Do you really prefer muffin?
Mind the patty-pan!
May I pass you the marmalade?

A little more bacon, my dear
Duchess?

Thank you, my dear Ribby; I
was only feeling for the patty-pan.

Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby;
where can it have gone to?

There most certainly is not one,
my dear Duchess. I disapprove of
tin articles in puddings and pies. It
is most undesirable--(especially
when people swallow in lumps!)

My Great-aunt Squintina
(grandmother of Cousin Tabitha
Twitchit)--died of a thimble in a
Christmas plum-pudding. _I_ never
put any article of metal in MY
puddings or pies.

I have only four patty-pans,
and they are all in the cupboard.

I shall die! I shall die! I have
swallowed a patty-pan! Oh, my
dear Ribby, I do feel so ill!

It is impossible, my dear
Duchess; there was not a patty-pan.

Oh I feel so dreadful. I have
swallowed a patty-pan!
There was NOTHING in the pie,

Yes there WAS, my dear Ribby,
I am sure I have swallowed it!

Let me prop you up with a
pillow, my dear Duchess; where do
you think you feel it?

Oh I do feel so ill ALL OVER me,
my dear Ribby; I have swallowed
a large tin patty-pan with a sharp
scalloped edge!

Shall I run for the doctor? I
will just lock up the spoons!

Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty,
my dear Ribby: he is a Pie
himself, he will certainly understand.

How COULD I have swallowed it!
such a large thing as a patty-pan!

No; there is no patty-pan, and
I put one in; and nobody has eaten
pie except me, so I must have
swallowed it!

Then I must have been eating
MOUSE! . . . NO wonder I feel ill.
. . . But perhaps I should feel worse
if I had really swallowed a patty-
pan!
I am feeling very much better,
I am truly glad to hear it!

I think I should feel QUITE well
if he only felt my pulse,

It is only a bread pill, you had
much better take it; drink a little
milk, my dear Duchess!

Gammon
and spinach!
ha ha HA!

I am feeling very much better,
my dear Ribby,

Do you not think that I had better
go home before it gets dark?

Perhaps it might be wise, my
dear Duchess. I will lend you a
nice warm shawl, and you shall
take my arm.

I would not trouble you for
worlds; I feel wonderfully better.
One pill of Dr. Maggotty----

Indeed it is most admirable, if
it has cured you of a patty-pan! I
will call directly after breakfast to
ask how you have slept.

Did you ever see the like! so there
really WAS a patty-pan? . . . . But
my patty-pans are all in the kitchen
cupboard. Well I never did! . . . .
Next time I want to give a party
--I will invite Cousin Tabitha
Twitchit!

I wish to hatch my own
eggs; I will hatch them all
by myself,

Indeed! how interesting!
I wish I could meet with that
fowl. I would teach it to mind
its own business!

THIS is my summer
residence; you would not
find my earth--my winter
house--so convenient,

column18:
What are you
doing with those onions?
Where do you go every afternoon
by yourself, Jemima
Puddle-duck?

column1:
Come into the house as
soon as you have looked at
your eggs. Give me the herbs
for the omelette. Be sharp!

column27:
Yus, yus, yus! they
eat and indeed they DO eat!

column1:
Aunt Pettitoes, Aunt Pettitoes!
you are a worthy person, but your
family is not well brought up.
Every one of them has been in
mischief except Spot and Pigling
Bland.

column27:
And they drink
bucketfuls of milk; I shall have to
get another cow! Good little Spot
shall stay at home to do the
housework; but the others must go.
Four little boy pigs and four little
girl pigs are too many altogether.

column1:
there will be more to eat without
them.

Observe sign-posts and milestones;
do not gobble herring bones--

if you once cross the county
boundary you cannot come back.

Alexander, you are not attending.
Here are two licences permitting
two pigs to go to market in
Lancashire. Attend, Alexander. I have
had no end of trouble in getting
these papers from the policeman.

What's that, young sirs? Stole
a pig? Where are your licences?

column27:
I had one, indeed I had, Mr.
Policeman!

I see no reason, young sir;
your paper is all right.

column1:
I wish I could have a little
garden and grow potatoes,

column18:
Wee, wee, wee! I can't
find my way home!

column1: You can't go in the dark,

Do you know your way by
daylight?

I know we can see this little
white house from the hills across
the river. Which way are YOU
going, Mr. Pig?

To market--I have two pig
papers. I might take you to the
bridge; if you have no objection,
I thought you had eaten them,

I wish you wouldn't; he might
smell them through the ceiling,

You will not mind if I say iddy
tidditty? I have forgotten some of
the words.

The cock has crowed; we must
start before the hens come out; they
might shout to Mr. Piperson.

Come away Pig-wig; we can see
when we get used to it. Come!
I can hear them clucking!

Come, Pig-wig, we must get to
the bridge before folks are stirring.

I don't want; I want to
grow potatoes.

Take that peppermint out of
your mouth, Pig-wig, we may have
to run. Don't say one word. Leave
it to me. And in sight of the bridge!

I thought as much. It was
yesterday. Show me your licence?

This here pig is a young
lady; is her name Alexander?

It is not boiled enough; it
is hard. You have a try,
Hunca Munca.

It's as hard as the hams
at the cheesemonger's,

column27:
give me some fish,
Hunca Munca!

column1:
I will get a doll dressed like a
policeman!

column8:
How do you do, Mistress Pussy?
    Mistress Pussy, how do you do?

I thank you kindly, little dog,
    I fare as well as you!

I'm little Tom Tinker's dog,
      Bow, wow, wow!

column29:
you may go into
the fields or down the lane, but don't
go into Mr. McGregor's garden: your
Father had an accident there; he was
put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor.

column27:
Now run along, and don't get into
mischief. I am going out.

One table-spoonful to be taken at
bed-time.

I'll be at charges for a looking-glass;
And entertain a score or two of tailors.

column35:
No breadth at
all, and cut on the cross; it is no
breadth at all; tippets for mice and
ribbons for mobs! for mice!

column29:
Simpkin, we
shall make our fortune, but I am
worn to a ravelling. Take this groat
(which is our last fourpence), and,
Simpkin, take a china pipkin, but a
penn'orth of bread, a penn'orth of
milk, and a penn'orth of sausages.
And oh, Simpkin, with the last penny
of our fourpence but me one
penn'orth of cherry-coloured silk. But
do not lose the last penny of the
fourpence, Simpkin, or I am undone
and worn to a thread-paper, for I
have NO MORE TWIST.

column27:
I shall make my fortune--to be
cut bias--the Mayor of Gloucester is
to be married on Christmas Day in the
morning, and he hath ordered a coat
and an embroidered waistcoat--

column7:
One-and-twenty
buttonholes of cherry-coloured silk!
To be finished by noon of Saturday:
and this is Tuesday evening. Was it
right to let loose those mice,
undoubtedly the property of Simpkin?
Alack, I am undone, for I have no
more twist!

No more twist! no
more twist!

column29:
No more
twist! No more twist!

column35:
I have my
twist; but no more strength--nor
time--than will serve to make me one
single buttonhole; for this is
Christmas Day in the Morning! The
Mayor of Gloucester shall be married
by noon--and where is his cherry-
coloured coat?

column27:
Old Mr. Brown, will you
favour us with permission to
gather nuts upon your island?

column5:
Riddle me, riddle me, rot-tot-tote!
     A little wee man, in a red red coat!
     A staff in his hand, and a stone in his throat;
     If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a groat.

column27:
Mr. Brown, will you favour us with
your gracious permission to gather
some more nuts?

column5:
Old Mr. B! riddle-me-ree!
     Flour of England, fruit of Spain,
     Met together in a shower of rain;
     Put in a bag tied round with a string,
     If you'll tell me this riddle,
     I'll give you a ring!

Hum-a-bum! buzz! buzz! Hum-a-bum buzz!
          As I went over Tipple-tine
          I met a flock of bonny swine;
     Some yellow-nacked, some yellow backed!
          They were the very bonniest swine
          That e'er went over the Tipple-tine.

Humpty Dumpty lies in the beck,
     With a white counterpane round his neck,
     Forty doctors and forty wrights,
     Cannot put Humpty Dumpty to rights!

Old Mr. B! Old Mr. B!
     Hickamore, Hackamore, on the King's
          kitchen door;
     All the King's horses, and all the King's men,
     Couldn't drive Hickamore, Hackamore,
     Off the King's kitchen door!

Authur O'Bower has broken his band,
     He comes roaring up the land!
     The King of Scots with all his power,
     Cannot turn Arthur of the Bower!

column7:
The scarecrow in Mr.
McGregor's garden,

column12:
Cotton-tail! Cotton-tail! fetch
some more camomile!

column29:
It spoils
people's clothes to squeeze under a
gate; the proper way to get in is to
climb down a pear-tree.

column27:
It is not boiled enough; it is hard.
You have a try, Hunca Munca.

It's as hard as the hams at the
cheesemonger's,
give me some fish, Hunca Munca!

I've lost my pocket-handkin! Three
handkins and a pinny! Have YOU seen
them, Tabby Kitten?

Sally Henny-penny, have YOU
found three pocket-handkins?

column5:
Lily-white and clean, oh!
     With little frills between, oh!
     Smooth and hot-red rusty spot
     Never here be seen, oh!

column27:
Oh no, if you please'm; that's a
little scarlet waist-coat belonging to
Cock Robin!

Oh no, if you please'm; that's a
damask table-cloth belonging to
Jenny Wren; look how it's stained with
currant wine! It's very bad to wash!

There's one of my pocket-
handkins!

And what are those long yellow
things with fingers like gloves?

Oh that's a pair of stockings
belonging to Sally Henny-penny--look
how she's worn the heels out with
scratching in the yard! She'll very soon
go barefoot!

Why, there's another hankersniff--
but it isn't mine; it's red?

Oh no, if you please'm; that one
belongs to old Mrs. Rabbit; and it DID
so smell of onions! I've had to wash it
separately, I can't get out that smell.
What are those funny little white things?

That's a pair of mittens belonging
to Tabby Kitten; I only have to iron
them; she washes them herself.

And what are you dipping into the
basin of starch?

They're little dicky shirt-fronts
belonging to Tom Titmouse--most
terrible particular!

column12:
Now I've finished my ironing;
I'm going to air some clothes.

column27:
What are these dear soft fluffy
things?

Oh those are woolly coats
belonging to the little lambs at
Skelghyl.

Oh yes, if you please'm; look at the
sheep-mark on the shoulder. And
here's one marked for Gatesgarth,
and three that come from Little-town.
They're ALWAYS marked at washing!

column5: I thank you kindly, little dog, I fare as well as you!

column27:
Come in good time, my dear
Duchess,
column35:
and we
will have something so very nice. I am

anything so good! And YOU shall eat it
all! _I_ will eat muffins, my dear
Duchess!

column27:
I will come very punctually, my
dear Ribby,

I am dreadfully afraid it WILL be
mouse!

Oh what a good idea! Why
shouldn't I rush along and put my pie
into Ribby's oven when Ribby isn't
there?
The top oven bakes too quickly,

pie was NOT in the oven when I put

MY pie into a nice hot oven at the top.
I could not turn any of the other

but I wish I

column27:
Come in! and how do you do, my

column29:
I hope I
see you well?

column27:
Quite well, I thank you, and how
do YOU do, my dear Ribby?

column12:
I've brought you some
flowers; what a delicious smell of pie!

column27:
Oh, what lovely flowers! Yes, it is
mouse and bacon!
I think it wants another five minutes,

column7:
Just a shade longer; I will
pour out the tea, while we wait.
Do you take sugar, my dear Duchess?

column27:
Oh yes, please! my dear Ribby; and
may I have a lump upon my nose?

How good that pie smells! I do
love veal and ham--I mean to say
mouse and bacon--

I will first cut the pie for you; I am
going to have muffin and
marmalade,

A little more bacon, my dear
Duchess?

Thank you, my dear Ribby; I was
only feeling for the patty-pan.

The patty pan that held up the
pie-crust,

Oh, I didn't put one in, my dear
Duchess,
column29:
I don't think
that it is necessary in pies made of

column27:
Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby; where
can it have gone to?

I have only four patty-pans, and
they are all in the cupboard.

I shall die! I shall die! I have
swallowed a patty-pan! Oh, my dear
Ribby, I do feel so ill!

It is impossible, my dear Duchess;
there was not a patty-pan.

Yes there WAS, my dear Ribby, I am

Let me prop you up with a pillow,
my dear Duchess; where do you think
you feel it?

Oh I do feel so ill ALL OVER me, my
dear Ribby.
Shall I run for the doctor?

Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty,

How COULD I have swallowed it!
such a large thing as a patty-pan!

Then I must have been eating
MOUSE! . . . No wonder I feel ill. . . .
But perhaps I should feel worse if I

I am feeling very much better,

I am truly glad to hear it! He has
brought you a pill, my dear Duchess!

I think I should feel QUITE well if he
only felt my pulse,

much better take it; drink a little milk,

I am feeling very much better, my
dear Ribby,
column29:
Do you
not think that I had better go home

column27:
Perhaps it might be wise, my dear
Duchess.

Did you ever see the like! so there
really WAS a patty-pan? . . . But MY
patty-pans are all in the kitchen
cupboard. Well I never did! . . . Next
time I want to give a party--I will
invite Cousin Tabitha Twitchit!

column27: I know a good place for minnows,

This is getting tiresome, I think I
should like some lunch,

I will eat a butterfly sandwich,
and wait till the shower is over,
I trust that is not a rat,

column7:
I think I had better get
away from here.

column27:

column5:

What a mercy that was not a
pike!

ducks.

on the garden wall,

My friends will arrive in a minute,

would!

I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will
hatch them all by myself,
Madam, have you lost your way?

This is my summer residence; you
would not find my earth--my winter
house--so convenient,

column12:

column27:
Come into the house as soon as

the herbs for the omelet. Be sharp!

afraid the rats have got him.

He's a bad kitten, Cousin Tabitha;

bonnet last time I came to tea. Where
have you looked for him?

All over the house! The rats are too
many for me. What a thing it is to
have an unruly family!

I'm not afraid of rats; I will help
you to find him; and whip him, too!
What is all that soot in the fender?
Yes, it is infested with rats,
Here's one of your kittens at least,

column12:
there's been an old woman
rat in the kitchen, and she's stolen

column27: Which way did she go, Moppet?

Oh! Mother, Mother, there has
been an old man rat in the dairy--a
dreadful 'normous big rat, Mother;
and he's stolen a pat of butter and the
rolling pin.

A rolling pin and butter! Oh, my
poor son Thomas!

column29:
Did we
not hear a roly-poly noise in the attic
when we were looking into that
chest?

column7:
We must send for John

column27:
I cannot go back. If I slipped I

jacket.

column12:
Who has been gnawing bones
up here in the chimney? I wish I had

It is something like mouse, only
dreadfully strong. It makes me
sneeze,

column27:
What do you mean by tumbling
into my bed all covered with smuts?

Please, sir, the chimney wants
sweeping,

Anna Maria, make me a kitten
dumpling roly-poly pudding for my
dinner.

It requires dough and a pat of
butter and a rolling pin,

column35:
make
it properly, Anna Maria, with

column27:
Will not the string be very
indigestible, Anna Maria?

fetch enough dough, Anna Maria.

I fetched as much as I could
carry,

But I am persuaded that the knots
would have proved indigestible,
whatever you may urge to the
contrary.

Come away at once and help me
to tie up some mutton bones in a
counterpane,
column35:
I
have got half a smoked ham hidden in

column27:
One, two, three, four! five! six
leetle rabbits!

One, two, three, four, five, six
leetle rabbits!

Eh? What's that? What have
they been spoiling now?

One, two, three, four, five, six
leetle fat rabbits!

Don't you be silly: what do you
mean, you silly old man?

In the sack! one, two, three,
four, five, six!

Not fit to eat; but the skins will
do fine to line my old cloak.

Rabbit tobacco! I shall skin
them and cut off their heads.

Your house is on fire, Mother
Ladybird! Fly away home to your
children!

Beg pardon, is this not Miss

Go away, you bold bad spider!
Leaving ends of cobweb all over

I smell a smell of honey; is it

I am sure I can see the marks of
little dirty feet.

Good-day, Babbitty Bumble; I
should be glad to buy some bees-
wax. But what are you doing

come in at a window, and say,
Zizz, Bizz, Bizzz?

I am not in the habit of letting
lodgings; this is an intrusion!

How do you do, Mr. Jackson?
Deary me, you have got
very wet!

Thank you, thank you,
thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!
I'll sit awhile and dry myself,

column12:
Thank you, thank you,

column27:

you, Mrs. Tittlemouse! Now what

any, Mr. Jackson!

column29:
I can SMELL it;
that is why I came to call.

column27:
Indeed, indeed, you will stick
fast, Mr. Jackson!

Tiddly, widdly, widdly? No

I do not like bumble bees. They
are all over bristles,
Get out, you nasty old toad!

Then we shall

We

Timmy Tiptoes! Timmy Tip-

I am sure I beg your pardon; I

a glass of my daughter Flopsy's

column27:
Cousin Peter! Peter Rabbit, Peter
Rabbit!

No, no, no! He's bagged my
family--Tommy Brock--in a sack
--have you seen him?

Tommy Brock? how many,
Cousin Benjamin?

Seven, Cousin Peter, and all of
them twins! Did he come this way?
Please tell me quick!

Yes, yes; not ten minutes since
... he said they were CATERPILLARS;
I did think they were kicking rather
hard, for caterpillars.

Which way? which way has he
gone, Cousin Peter?

He had a sack with something
live in it; I watched him set a mole
trap. Let me use my mind, Cousin
Benjamin; tell me from the beginning,

but there are two hopeful
circumstances. Your family is alive and
kicking; and Tommy Brock has had
refreshments. He will probably go
to sleep, and keep them for breakfast.

column12:
Cousin Benjamin,
compose yourself. I know
very well which way. Because Mr.
Tod was at home in the stick house
he has gone to Mr. Tod's other
house, at the top of Bull Banks. I
partly know, because he offered to
leave any message at Sister Cottontail's;
he said he would be passing.

column27:
He must be very puffed; we are
close behind him, by the scent.
What a nasty person!

column5:
They live
too near the rocks to quarrel with
their neighbors. Come on, Cousin
Benjamin!

column27:
Oh my poor rabbit babies!
What a dreadful place; I shall never
see them again!

It will make a great mess in my
bedroom; but I could never sleep in
that bed again without a spring
cleaning of some sort,

I will wake him up with an
unpleasant surprise,

I will bury that nasty person in
the hole which he has dug. I will
bring my bedding out, and dry it in
the sun,

I will wash the tablecloth and
spread it on the grass in the sun to
bleach. And the blanket must be
hung up in the wind; and the bed
must be thoroughly disinfected,
and aired with a warming-pan;
and warmed with a hot water bottle.

I will get soft soap, and monkey
soap, and all sorts of soap; and
soda and scrubbing brushes; and
persian powder; and carbolic to
remove the smell. I must have a
disinfecting. Perhaps I may have to
burn sulphur.

First I will arrange the hole--then
I will drag out that person in the
blanket. . . .

Now for it! Run in, Cousin
Benjamin! Run in and get them! while
I watch the door.
Oh; oh! they are coming back!

What dreadful bad language! I
think they have fallen down the
stone quarry.

Be quick, it's all right. Shut the
oven door, Cousin Benjamin, so
that he won't miss them.

I've got them! Can we get away?
Shall we hide, Cousin Peter?

Aunt Pettitoes, Aunt Pettitoes!
you are a worthy person, but your
family is not well brought up.
Every one of them has been in
mischief except Spot and Pigling
Bland.

And they drink bucketfuls of milk;
I shall have to get another cow!
Good little Spot shall stay at home
to do the housework; but the others
must go. Four little boy pigs and
four little girl pigs are too many
altogether.

column7:
there will be more
to eat without them.

column27:

Bland, you must go to market. Take

and remember to blow your nose

if you once cross the

back. Alexander, you are not
attending. Here are two licenses

have had no end of trouble in getting
these papers from the policeman.

column27:
What's that, young Sirs? Stole a
pig? Where are your licenses?

column12:
I had one, indeed I had, Mr.
Policeman!

column27:
It's not likely they let you start
without. I am passing the farm.
You may walk with me.

column12:
I see no reason, young Sir;
your paper is all right.

column27:
I wish I could have a little garden
and grow potatoes,

column7:
Wee, wee, wee! I can't

column27:
Bacon and eggs, bacon and

This one's come of himself,
whatever,

column35:

I wish you wouldn't; he might
smell them through the ceiling,

I am sorry. . . I have tooth-
ache,

iddy tidditty? I have forgotten some

column12:
I don't want; I want to

column29:
Pig-wig! keep under

I thought as much. It was
yesterday. Show me your license?

Send in all the bills again to everybody 'with comp'ts,'

I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself,

This is my summer residence; you would not find my earth--my winter
house--so convenient,

Come into the house as soon as you have looked at your eggs. Give me the

Why don't those youngsters come back with the dessert?

No? Would you rather go to bed? I will show you a most comfortable

column17:
It sounds rather a dull place? What do you do when it
rains?

column25:
When it rains, I sit in my little sandy burrow and shell corn and
seeds from my Autumn store. I peep out at the throstles and blackbirds
on the lawn, and my friend Cock Robin. And when the sun comes out again,
you should see my garden and the flowers--roses and pinks and
pansies--no noise except the birds and bees, and the lambs in the
meadows.
Oh yes, yes, you have been most kind; but I do feel so ill,

It may be that your teeth and digestion are unaccustomed to our food;
perhaps it might be wiser for you to return in the hamper.

column26:
that is only a cow; I will beg a little
milk, they are quite harmless, unless they happen to lie down upon you.

column25: They say we did it; but I know better,

That is only the lawn-mower; I will fetch some of the grass clippings
presently to make your bed. I am sure you had better settle in the
country, Johnny.

H'm'm--we shall see by Tuesday week; the hamper is stopped while they
are at the sea-side.
I am sure you will never want to live in town again,
This is getting tiresome, I think I should like some lunch,
I will eat a butterfly sandwich, and wait till the shower is over,

Lily-white and clean, oh!

Smooth and hot--red rusty spot
Never here be seen, oh!

AND what are those long
yellow things with fingers
like gloves?

WHY, there's another
handkersniff--but it
isn't mine; it's red?

Oh no, if you please'm;
that one belongs to old Mrs.
Rabbit; and it did so smell
of onions!  I've had to wash
it separately, I can't get out
the smell.

WHAT are those funny
little white things?

That's a pair of mittens
belonging to Tabby Kitten;
I only have to iron them; she
washes then herself.

AND what are you dipping
into the basin of starch?

They're little dicky shirt-fronts
belonging to Tom Tits-mouse
--most terrible particular!

Now I've finished my ironing;
I'm going to air some clothes.

WHAT are these dear soft
fluffy things?

Oh those are woolly coats
belonging to the little lambs
at Skelghyl.

I am afraid I have not got any, Mr. Jackson,

What is all that soot in the fender?

They have both got out of the cupboard!
Yes, it is infested with rats,
column32:
I caught seven
young ones out of one hole in the back kitchen, and we had them for
dinner last Saturday. And once I saw the old father rat--an enormous old
rat, Cousin Ribby. I was just going to jump upon him, when he showed his
yellow teeth at me and whisked down the hole.

column25: The rats get upon my nerves, Cousin Ribby,

there's been an old woman rat in the

column34: Don't you be silly; what do you mean, you silly old man?

column10:
and we
will have something so very nice. I am baking it in a pie-dish--a
pie-dish with a pink rim. You never tasted anything so good! And _you_
shall eat it all! _I_ will eat muffins, my dear Duchess!
column33: Come in good time, my dear Duchess,
I will come very punctually, my dear Ribby,
I am dreadfully afraid it _will_ be mouse!

It is all ready to put into the oven. Such lovely pie-crust; and I
put in a little tin patty-pan to hold up the crust; and I made a hole
in the middle with a fork to let out the steam--Oh I do wish I could
eat my own pie, instead of a pie made of mouse!

A pink and white pie-dish--and _you_ shall eat it _all_. 'You' means
me--then Ribby is not going to even taste the pie herself? A pink and
white pie-dish! Ribby is sure to go out to buy the muffins.... Oh what
a good idea! Why shouldn't I rush along and put my pie into Ribby's
oven when Ribby isn't there?

column25:
It is a pie
of the most delicate and tender mouse minced up with bacon. And I have
taken out all the bones; because Duchess did nearly choke herself with
a fish-bone last time I gave a party. She eats a little fast--rather
big mouthfuls. But a most genteel and elegant little dog; infinitely
superior company to Cousin Tabitha Twitchit.
column33: The top oven bakes too quickly,

A little _dog_ indeed! Just as if there were no CATS in Sawrey!
And a _pie_ for afternoon tea! The very idea!
I trust that is not that Pie: the spoons are locked up, however,

It is a very odd thing that Ribby's pie was _not_ in the oven when I
put mine in! And I can't find it anywhere; I have looked all over the
house. I put _my_ pie into a nice hot oven at the top. I could not
turn any of the other handles; I think that they are all shams,

column4:
but I wish I could have removed the pie made of mouse! I
cannot think what she has done with it? I heard Ribby coming and I had
to run out by the back door!

column15:
I did not _think_ I left that
drawer pulled out; has somebody been trying on my mittens?

column33: I wonder if Ribby has taken _my_ pie out of the oven yet?

column4:
and whatever can have become of the other pie made of
mouse?

column15:
I hope I
see you well?
column33: Come in! and how do you do, my dear Duchess?
Quite well, I thank you, and how do _you_ do, my dear Ribby?

column4:
I've brought you some flowers; what a delicious smell of
pie!

column33: Oh, what lovely flowers! Yes, it is mouse and bacon!

column15:
what a lovely
white tea-cloth!... Is it done to a turn? Is it still in the oven?
column33: Do not talk about food, my dear Ribby,

column15:
Just a shade
longer; I will pour out the tea, while we wait. Do you take sugar, my
dear Duchess?
column33: I think it wants another five minutes,
Oh yes, please! my dear Ribby; and may I have a lump upon my nose?

With pleasure, my dear Duchess; how beautifully you beg! Oh, how
sweetly pretty!

How good that pie smells! I do love veal and ham--I mean to say mouse
and bacon--

I will first cut the pie for you; I am going to have muffin and
marmalade,
Do you really prefer muffin? Mind the patty-pan!
May I pass you the marmalade?
Thank you, my dear Ribby; I was only feeling for the patty-pan.
The patty-pan that held up the pie-crust,

column15:
I don't think
that it is necessary in pies made of mouse.
column33: Oh, I didn't put one in, my dear Duchess,
Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby; where can it have gone to?

There most certainly is not one, my dear Duchess. I disapprove of tin
articles in puddings and pies. It is most undesirable--(especially
when people swallow in lumps!)

My Great-aunt Squintina (grandmother of Cousin Tabitha
Twitchit)--died of a thimble in a Christmas plum-pudding. _I_ never
put any article of metal in _my_ puddings or pies.
I have only four patty-pans, and they are all in the cupboard.

I shall die! I shall die! I have swallowed a patty-pan! Oh, my dear
Ribby, I do feel so ill!
It is impossible, my dear Duchess; there was not a patty-pan.
Oh I feel so dreadful, I have swallowed a patty-pan!
Yes there _was_, my dear Ribby, I am sure I have swallowed it!

Let me prop you up with a pillow, my dear Duchess; where do you think
you feel it?

Oh I do feel so ill _all over_ me, my dear Ribby; I have swallowed a
large tin patty-pan with a sharp scalloped edge!
Shall I run for the doctor? I will just lock up the spoons!

Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty, my dear Ribby: he is a Pie himself,
he will certainly understand.
How _could_ I have swallowed it! such a large thing as a patty-pan!

No; there is no patty-pan, and I put one in; and nobody has eaten pie
except me, so I must have swallowed it!

Then I must have been eating MOUSE!... No wonder I feel ill.... But
perhaps I should feel worse if I had really swallowed a patty-pan!

I am truly glad to hear it! He has brought you a pill, my dear
Duchess!
I think I should feel _quite_ well if he only felt my pulse,

It is only a bread pill, you had much better take it; drink a little
milk, my dear Duchess!
Gammon and Spinach! ha ha HA!

column15:
Do you
not think that I had better go home before it gets dark?
column33: I am feeling very much better my dear Ribby,

Perhaps it might be wise, my dear Duchess. I will lend you a nice
warm shawl, and you shall take my arm.

I would not trouble you for worlds; I feel wonderfully better. One
pill of Dr. Maggotty--

Indeed it is most admirable, if it has cured you of a patty-pan! I
will call directly after breakfast to ask how you have slept.

column25: How shall you ever get them out again? It is like a money-box!
Timmy Tiptoes! Timmy Tiptoes! Oh, where is Timmy Tiptoes?

It is getting perfectly full-up down-stairs; the sitting-room is full,
and they are rolling along the passage; and my husband, Chippy Hackee, has
run away and left me. What is the explanation of these showers of nuts?
I am sure I beg your pardon; I did not know that anybody lived here,
You could squeeze in, through that little round hole,

column1: ('Now keep your frocks clean, children! You must walk on your hind legs.\r\nKeep away from the dirty ash-pit, and from Sally Henny Penny, and from the\r\npig-stye and the Puddle-Ducks.', nan)
('Let us climb up the rockery, and sit on the garden wall,', 'said')
